text: can you imagine running all by yourself
on the streets of Pyongyang for two
hours with thousands of North Koreans on
the sidelines cheering you on and more
importantly nobody telling you what you
can and can't do that's what I did last
April on my life-changing trip to North
Korea it was a thrilling
once-in-a-lifetime event that still had
me giddy as I tell you this story every
year about 2,000 participants gathered
to run in one of the most exciting
weekend's of the year it's not Matthew
we are ready to rock and roll yes we are
Judas the field is about half locals fat
foreigners along with a few professional
runners we started and ended the
marathon in a massive stadium filled to
capacity with 50,000 screaming Koreans I
can't describe the adrenaline rush that
I had inside of that stadium all runners
have the option to run a 10k half
marathon or full marathon I opted for
the 10k because a I'm not a runner and B
I used this opportunity to mingle around
and interact with the locals it was more
of a 10k walk than a run for me everyone
who I came in contact with was friendly
and supportive cheering me on giving me
high-fives
giving me motivation 2590 funny buddy
and making me feel happy even after the
event finished there were beer tents
outside where locals could hang out with
foreigners yes they serve beer in North
Korea first running in the Pyongyang
marathon was the only time when I didn't
have to stay with our group I was free
to run anywhere within the marked off
boundaries I was able to fully embrace
the North Korean ambience it was awesome
this probably isn't what you'd expect
when thinking about North Korea but it
was a unique experience that I wanted to
share with you and the highlight of my
trip that I'll never ever forget
[Music]
